translated_text:
A
This Saturday morning and morning are marked by the continuation of the conflict between Ukraine and Russia, which continues to haunt both Ukrainian and European citizens. Although there is an environment of constant tension and many countries try to help, there are others that are
intend to abstain
.
Kiev dawned after a night marked by
missiles
,
shooting
and explosions in a country trying to defend itself from Russian troops. António Guterres asks for a
"new chance for peace"
, already Emmanuel Macron, warned today that the war
"it will last"
.
Portugal is part of the 50 UN countries that promised to condemn Russia to the organization's General Assembly because they consider that
"Putin is the aggressor"
from Ukraine.
Follow the latest developments on the conflict in Ukraine here BY THE MINUTE:
3:01 p.m.
-
We close the morning registration here. You can continue to follow the afternoon incidents
here
.
15h00 -
Shengelia leaves CSKA: "I can't play for the Russian army club"
Tornike Shengelia, a Georgian basketball player who has played in the NBA for the Brooklyn Nets and Chicago Bulls, announced this Saturday that
will leave CSKA
, the club he represents, due to the situation in Ukraine.
2:54 pm -
The marks of war reach the civilian outskirts of Kiev
Smoke still escapes from one of the three floors of a residential building next to the Zhiliany civil airport
today was hit by a missile
of Russian aviation, in the latest "side effect" of a conflict with no end in sight.
2:46 pm -
President of Lithuania calls on Russia to "stop all this"
Lithuanian President Gitanas Nausėda said that "even though a lot of harm has already been done, it is not too late to stop all this."
Я обращаюсь к вам, люди
#России
. Еще не поздно. But it's a long time ago, but it's not so long ago.
I appeal to you people of
#Russia
. It's not too late. Even though much evil has been committed, it's not too late yet to stop all of this.
pic.twitter.com/1PLBSAROPg
— Gitanas Nausėda (@GitanasNauseda)
February 26, 2022
2:37 pm -
Estonia bans Russian airlines from airspace
The announcement was made by the Prime Minister of Estonia on social media, where she invited "all European Union (EU) countries to do the same", adding: "There is no place for planes from the aggressor state in democratic skies".
#Estonia
is banning Russian airlines from our airspace. We invite all EU countries to do the same. There is no place for plans of the aggressor state in democratic skies.
#StandWithUkraine
—Kaja Kallas (@kajakallas)
February 26, 2022
2:31 pm -
Borrell believes UN vote shows global "rejection" of Russia
The European Union (EU) High Representative for Foreign Policy said today that the UN vote on a resolution against Russia's invasion of Ukraine demonstrates the
"rejection" of the military campaign
by the international community.
2:26 pm -
Nélson Monte's first message after escaping from Ukraine
Nélson Monte used social media early this Saturday afternoon to publish the
first message since he managed to leave Ukraine
, following the invasion by Russian military forces over the last few days.
View this post on Instagram
A post shared by Nelson Monte (@nelsonmonte)
2:19 pm -
Boris Johnson explains how the UK is supporting Ukraine
The UK Prime Minister shared what measures the UK is taking to assist Ukraine.
How the UK is supporting Ukraine.
#StandWithUkraine
🇺🇦🇬🇧
pic.twitter.com/nx476LxjAc
— Boris Johnson (@BorisJohnson)
February 26, 2022
2:13 pm -
Szczesny supports Polish boycott: "I refuse to play against Russia"
Wojciech Szczesny took to social media early this Saturday afternoon to demonstrate his
support for the measure taken
, hours earlier, by the Polish Federation, which rejected facing Russia in the qualifying playoffs for the World Cup.
2:04 pm -
France supports Moldova and Georgia against possible destabilization
French President Emmanuel Macron expressed his support for
Moldova and Georgia
against possible attempts to destabilize these countries, during conversations with the Moldovan and Georgian counterparts.
13:59 -
Kate Middleton and William stand in solidarity with Ukraine
Another message of support for the Ukrainian people arrives from the British royal family. In a post made on Twitter, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge
remember the moment they met the president of Ukraine
, Volodymyr Zelensky, and his wife, Olena Zelenska.
In October 2020 we had the privilege to meet President Zelenskyy and the First Lady to learn of their hope and optimism for Ukraine’s future.
Today we stand with the President and all of Ukraine’s people as they bravely fight for that future 🇺🇦 W & C
— The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (@KensingtonRoyal)
February 26, 2022
13:56 -
Nine Latin American countries prepare plan to evacuate citizens
The governments of nine Latin American countries are working on a
"joint withdrawal plan"
of its citizens in Ukraine, through a "consular cooperation" mechanism, the Argentine Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced today.
1:53 pm -
Turkey calls on Russia to end the military operation
The Turkish Foreign Minister today appealed to his Russian counterpart, in a telephone conversation, to
put an end to the military operation in Ukraine
, said Turkish diplomatic source.
13:49 -
Paulo Fonseca has already left Ukraine
The former coach of Rome, Shakhtar Donetsk, Sporting de Braga and FC Porto, among others,
left the Ukrainian capital
on Thursday, through the repatriation mission of the Portuguese embassy in Kiev, according to the same source contacted by Lusa.
1:45 pm -
President of Ukraine spoke with President of Turkey and Prime Minister of India
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky thanked his "friend" Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, President of Turkey, and the Turkish people for their support.
I thank my friend Mr. President of 🇹🇷
@RTErdogan
and the people of 🇹🇷 for their strong support. The ban on the passage of 🇷🇺 warships to the Black Sea and significant military and humanitarian support for 🇺🇦 are extremely important today. The people of 🇺🇦 will never forget that!
— Володимир Зеленський (@ZelenskyyUa)
February 26, 2022
In another post on his Twitter page, Zelensky shared that he spoke with the Indian Prime Minister, Narendra Modi, and that they are currently
more than 100,000 attackers in Ukraine
to attack residential buildings, thus requesting political support from India.
Spoke with 🇮🇳 Prime Minister
@narendramodi
. Informed of the course of 🇺🇦 repulsing 🇷🇺 aggression. More than 100,000 invaders are on our land. They insidiously fire on residential buildings. Urged 🇮🇳 to give us political support in🇺🇳 Security Council. Stop the aggressor together!
— Володимир Зеленський (@ZelenskyyUa)
February 26, 2022
1:36 pm -
Russia closes airspace to Bulgaria, Poland and Czech Republic
Russia today announced the closure of airspace to connections with
Bulgaria, Poland and the Czech Republic
, following an identical decision taken by Warsaw, Prague and Sofia, for Russian airlines.
1:32 pm -
"Planes dropped toys and cell phones with explosives inside"
Alexandre Pinto is a Portuguese man who lives in Ukraine and is currently in the city of Poltava, in the center of the country. Speaking to SIC Notícias, this Saturday morning, he stated: "I can say, for example, that since yesterday they have been reporting:
'Don't pick up anything from the ground'
, because here in a nearby city, in the district next to ours, planes passed by and dropped toys, cell phones and valuable products with explosives inside", he stated.
13:28 -
UK says Russian forces are 30 km from central Kiev
The British Ministry of Defense said today that it is in a position to confirm that Russian forces are continuing their approach to Kiev, being approximately
30 kilometers from the center of the capital
Ukrainian.
13:23 -
Russian Security Advisor threatens to withdraw from nuclear treaties
The vice-president of the Russian Security Council warned today that the country may choose to
exit the nuclear deal
and freeze Western assets in Russia, considering the sanctions to be proof of the West's "political impotence."
1:17 pm -
Ukraine. 15 of the 40 Portuguese people in the country have already asked for help to leave
The Minister of Foreign Affairs (MNE), Augusto Santos Silva, told Lusa today that there is
40 Portuguese still in Ukraine who want to leave
of the country, of which
15 have already asked the Portuguese authorities for help
. "We have an indication that around 40 want to leave, and of those, ten and a half have asked us for support to leave, and we are organizing that support," he said.
13:09 -
United Kingdom pressures FIFA to expel Russia from the World Cup
The United Kingdom will be discussing, internally,
new ways to pressure FIFA
moving towards the expulsion of Russia from the next World Cup, following the invasion of the country's military forces into Ukraine.
12:54 -
Putin ordered Russian troops to stop invasion yesterday
Vladimir Putin will have
ordered Russian troops to stop the invasion of Ukraine
, says the Kremlin. The request was made on Friday, but the military still ignored the order and continued to advance towards Kiev.
The information is being provided by Sky News, which states that it is believed that Russian troops will be around 30 kilometers from the center of Kiev. A Ukrainian minister says, however, that they could be closer.
12:44 -
80-year-old Ukrainian presents himself to the military to join the war
Image of the moment has already gone viral on social media and shows how
Ukrainians are committed to helping
, in any way possible, to defend your country.
Someone posted a photo of this 80-year-old who showed up to join the army, carrying with him a small case with 2 t-shirts, a pair of extra pants, a toothbrush and a few sandwiches for lunch. He said he was doing it for his grandkids.
pic.twitter.com/bemD24h6Ae
— Kateryna Yushchenko (@KatyaYushchenko)
February 24, 2022
12:31
-
EU meets energy ministers on Monday
France, which presides over the Council of the European Union,
announced today
an extraordinary meeting of the Council of Energy Ministers on Monday in Brussels, as
many European countries rely heavily on Russia for gas imports
.
12:26 p.m.
-
Almost 50 Portuguese left Ukraine and will be "repatriated"
Around 50 Portuguese people left Ukraine in the last few hours in missions organized by the Portuguese embassy in Kiev and will be repatriated in the next few hours,
the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, told Lusa today
.
12:10 -
Melitopol taken by the Russians. Flag raised at police station
Rumors that the coastal city of Melitopol, Ukraine,
was taken by Russian forces
This was confirmed this Saturday morning on social media, with the publication of videos showing an invaders' flag raised at the local police station.
🇺🇦Russian troops 🇷🇺 in the police station of Melitópol. (02/26/2022)
pic.twitter.com/v84DridER6
— Special Operators (@Spec_Operators)
February 26, 2022
12:02 -
Kiev decrees a mandatory curfew from 5pm (3pm in Lisbon)
The mayor of Kiev announced that anyone who does not comply with the curfew order from 5pm (3pm in Portugal) could be arrested, according to SIC Notícias. On social media, the mayor said that the curfew order lasts from 5 pm until 8 am the next day.
"All civilians who are on the street during this period will be considered members of enemy sabotage and reconnaissance groups,"
said Vitali Klitschko on the Telegram network
.
Kyiv's mayor has just announced a curfew in the city from 5:00pm to 8:00am. It will last until Feb 28. "All civilians who will be on the street during the curfew will be considered members of the enemy's sabotage and reconnaissance groups."
#Ukraine
https://t.co/HzQcuLo37M
— Harriet Tatham (@HarrietTatham)
February 26, 2022
11:47 am -
Deputy Prime Minister of Ukraine appealed to the International Red Cross
Iryna Vereshchuk, deputy prime minister of Ukraine, publicly asked the International Red Cross to help return Russian bodies to their homeland.
Deputy Prime Minister Iryna Vereshchuk appealed to the International Red Cross, urging the organization to help return the bodies of the
#Russian
occupants to their homeland.
pic.twitter.com/9FpvD2fYfL
— NEXTA (@nexta_tv)
February 26, 2022
11:32 am -
President of Ukraine spoke with President of Switzerland and Prime Minister of Greece
The Ukrainian president reports that he has received several calls of support. On the social network Twitter, he revealed that he spoke with the president of Switzerland and the prime minister of Greece, whom he thanks for the contact.
I'm getting support calls. Spoke with President of Switzerland
@ignaziocassis
and Prime Minister of Greece
@kmitsotakis
. Thank you for the decisions on concrete assistance to 🇺🇦!
— Володимир Зеленський (@ZelenskyyUa)
February 26, 2022
11h24 -
Zelensky asks Germany and Hungary for courage to remove Russia from SWIFT
The Ukrainian President
today called on Germany and Hungary to have "courage" to approve the exclusion of Russia
of the SWIFT interbank system, a measure analyzed by the EU in reaction to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
11h18 -
Ukraine president says EU promised him more "concrete support"
The President of the European Council, Charles Michel, today promised the Ukrainian head of state a new
"concrete support"
of the European bloc during a phone call made during the Russian offensive, Volodymyr Zelensky announced on Twitter. In the message, the Ukrainian President announced that he had contacted the former Prime Minister of Belgium to ask for more "concrete support" and to talk about the "heroic struggle of Ukrainians for their future".
11h11 -
The missile attack on a residential building seen from inside a room in Kiev
According to Dmytro Kuleba, Ukrainian foreign minister,
no fatalities were recorded
as a result of the missile attack on a residential building in Kiev. The president of the local chamber, Vitali Klitschko, specified that 35 people were injured, including two children.
In one room, a camera recorded the explosion.
pic.twitter.com/vHd4PkT7ln
— NEXTA (@nexta_tv)
February 26, 2022
11:03 -
Ukraine "broke the Russian plan" on the third day of invasion
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky assured today that
"broke the plan"
of Russia on the third day of the invasion of their country, asking Russians to tell Vladimir Putin to stop the war. "We maintained our position and successfully repelled enemy attacks. Fighting continues in many cities and regions of the country, but... it is our army that controls Kiev and the main cities around the capital," Zelensky said, in a video posted on Facebook.
10:58 -
Russian boat intercepted in the English Channel due to sanctions
A trade boat transporting vehicles to St. Petersburg, Russia, allegedly belonging to a Russian company targeted by European Union sanctions,
was diverted today in France
, according to local maritime authorities.
10:52 -
This war is not in "your name". Johnson speaks to Russians in Russian
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson recorded a message in which he stated, in Russian, and addressed to the people of Russia:
"I can't believe this war is being fought in your name"
, says EFE.
To the people of Ukraine: Slava Ukraini.
To the people of Russia: I do not believe this war is in your name.
This crisis, this tragedy, can and must come to an end. Because the world needs a free and sovereign Ukraine.
pic.twitter.com/ijbAAb8G67
— Boris Johnson (@BorisJohnson)
February 25, 2022
10:46 am -
One hundred thousand Ukrainians have entered Poland since Thursday
Polish Deputy Interior Minister Pawel Szefernaker said today that
100 thousand Ukrainians crossed the border into Poland
since the start of the Russian invasion on Thursday. "Since the beginning of war operations in Ukraine and to this day, along the entire border with Ukraine, one hundred thousand people have crossed the border into Poland," Szefernaker said.
10:40 am -
Ukraine. Order of Doctors calls for respect for human rights
The Order of Doctors today called for respect for human rights and medical neutrality in Ukraine, expressing
"high concern" and "total solidarity"
with the Ukrainian people, following the Russian invasion.
10:37 am -
Nélson Monte managed to escape to Romania and returns to Portugal today
Portuguese footballer Nélson Monte, who has been trying to leave Ukraine since Thursday,
already managed to reach Romania
, and will return to Portugal today, Joaquim Evangelista, president of the Players' Union, confirmed to Lusa.
10:34 -
Japan seeks to send more imported natural gas to Europe
Japan is negotiating with the European Union (EU) the
shipping more of its liquefied natural gas imports
(LNG) to Europe, given the possibility of Russia restricting exports after the invasion of Ukraine.
10:31 am -
Czech Republic will send weapons worth 7.6 million euros
The Czech Republic will ship to Ukraine
machine guns, automatic and precision rifles, pistols and ammunition worth 7.6 million
of euros, the Czech defense minister said today.
10h27 -
Zelensky asks the European Union to now decide to join the EU
The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky,
today asked the European Union (EU) to take a decision now
about your country's accession to the European bloc.
Ukraine is fighting the invader with weapons in hands, defending its freedom and European future. Discussed with
@vonderleyen
effective assistance to our country from 🇪🇺 in this heroic struggle. I believe that
#EU
also chooses Ukraine.
— Володимир Зеленський (@ZelenskyyUa)
February 26, 2022
10h24 -
Tuchel on Abramovich-Putin relationship: "The situation is horrible"
Thomas Tuchel, Chelsea coach, admitted on Friday afternoon that the relationship between Roman Abramovich, owner of the blues, and Vladimir Putin, president of Russia,
is affecting the London squad
.
10h18 -
Russia will respond to sanctions and suspend European collaboration in space launches
Dmitry Medvedev, deputy head of Moscow's security council, said this Saturday morning that funds from foreign countries and companies will be seized. According to Sky News, the Russian space agency Roskosmos will suspend cooperation with Europe on space launches from the Kourou spaceport in French Guiana.
10:12 am -
Poland refuses to face Russia in the World Cup playoff
Poland decided, this Saturday, that
will not face Russia
next March, where a duel is planned for the playoff to access the 2022 World Cup. The information was revealed on social media by Cezary Kulesza, president of the Polish Football Federation.
Koniec ze słowami, czas na czyny! W związku z eskalacją agresji Federacji Rosyjskiej na Ukrainę, reprezentacja Polski nie zamierza rozegrać barażowego meczu z rep. Rosji. To jedyna słuszna decyzja. Prowadzimy rozmowy z federacjami 🇸🇪 i 🇨🇿, aby przedstawić FIFA wspólne stanowisko.
— Cezary Kulesza (@Czarek_Kulesza)
February 26, 2022
10:03 -
Ukrainian president assures Macron that he keeps Kiev
The French President, Emmanuel Macron, and his Ukrainian counterpart, Volodymyr Zelensky, had a telephone conversation today in which he told him, according to Eliseu, that
maintains control of Kiev
, a city where fighting broke out in the streets that night.
9:57 am -
What are you doing?" Russian reprimands soldiers in Melitopol
O
video of a Russian grandfather
giving a reprimand to his country's soldiers for the invasion of Ukraine, filmed in the Zaporizhiam region, in Melitopol, went viral in the last few hours on social media. In this one, the man asks: "What are you doing here?"
9:46 am -
UN says that more than 120 thousand people have already fled to neighboring countries"
More than 120,000 people have fled Ukraine since Russia began attacking the neighboring country on Thursday, according to data from the United Nations Refugee Agency (UNHCR). According to UNHCR Deputy High Commissioner Kelly Clements,
Ukrainians are mainly fleeing to Poland and Moldova, but also to Romania, Slovakia and Hungary
.
9:41 am -
Italian PM supports Russia's disconnection from SWIFT
"This is the beginning of a new page in history", can be read in a publication made by the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky, where he explains that, in a telephone conversation, Mario Draghi, Italian Prime Minister,
supported Russia's disconnection from SWIFT
. In the end,  Zelensky reiterates
"Ukraine must become part of the European Union"
.
This is the beginning of a new page in the history of our states 🇺🇦 🇮🇹.
#MarioDraghi
in a phone conversation supported Russia's disconnection from SWIFT, the provision of defense assistance. Ukraine must become part of the
#EU
.
— Володимир Зеленський (@ZelenskyyUa)
February 26, 2022
9:34 am -
Kiev metro used only as a suspended air-raid shelter
According to The Kyiv Independent, the operation of the metro in the city of Kiev
is suspended
, serving only as an anti-aircraft shelter.
9h29 -
Thousands of Ukrainians cross the border and enter Romania
About
20 thousand people entered Romania
, coming from Ukraine, since the Russian army launched a military offensive against the Kiev regime on Thursday, Romanian authorities reported today.
9:23 am -
Angolan government will remove citizens residing in the affected areas
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Angola (MIREX) is working "hard" with its diplomatic representations in Russia and Poland to
remove Angolans living in areas of Ukraine affected by the conflict
.
9:17 am -
"Ammunition, not a ride." Zelensky refuses US help to leave Kiev
The United States offered help to remove Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, from Kiev, the capital of Ukraine, but the head of state refused the American offer.
"The fight is here. I need ammunition, not a ride"
, Zelensky said, according to a senior US intelligence official, cited by the Associated Press.
9:12 am -
Almost 200 Ukrainians killed in these three days of war
The Ukrainian Minister of Health, Viktor Lyashko, said that there are
198 deaths of Ukrainians, including three children
since the beginning of the invasion by Russia. As for the number of injured, there are already 1,115 people, including 33 children, and it is not clear whether these data refer only to civilians.
8:55 am
-
Zelensky says he spoke to the president of the European Commission
"Ukraine is fighting against the invader with weapons in hand, defending its freedom and the future of Europe. I discussed with [Ursula] von der Leyen effective support for our country by the European Union in this heroic fight.
I believe the EU is also on Ukraine's side
", indicated the Ukrainian president.
Ukraine is fighting the invader with weapons in hands, defending its freedom and European future. Discussed with
@vonderleyen
effective assistance to our country from 🇪🇺 in this heroic struggle. I believe that
#EU
also chooses Ukraine.
— Володимир Зеленський (@ZelenskyyUa)
February 26, 2022
8:15 am
-
Ukrainian president calls on people to defend Kiev
The president of Ukraine today asked the population not to lay down their arms and defend Kiev, where the Ukrainian army is already confronting Russian forces, two days after the start of the invasion.
"I'm here. We will not lay down our arms and we will defend our country"
,
declared Volodymyr Zelensky, in a video message published on the social network Facebook
.
Don't see fakers.
pic.twitter.com/wiLqmCuz1p
— Володимир Зеленський (@ZelenskyyUa)
February 26, 2022
8:10 am -
Attack on residential building with no deaths, but two injured children
According to Dmytro Kuleba, Ukrainian foreign minister, no fatalities were recorded as a result of the missile attack on a residential building in Kiev. The president of the local chamber, Vitali Klitschko, specified that 35 people were injured, including two children.
Cited by Reuters, an advisor to the Ministry of the Interior confirmed that there were no fatalities resulting from the attack. Anton Herashchenko stressed, however, that Russia is lying about not attacking civilian infrastructure, indicating that more than 40 such sites have already been attacked.

large residential building in Kiev was hit by a missile
, today indicated to AFP the State service for emergency issues, without providing information regarding possible victims.

French President Emmanuel Macron warned today that the war in Ukraine "will last" and that
everyone "must be prepared"
, indicating that the government is preparing a "resilience plan" to deal with the economic consequences of this crisis.
7:54 am -
Kremlin-backed media blocked from making money on Facebook
Facebook said on Friday that
blocked social media
supported by the Kremlin to make money on the social network, in response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
7:47 am -
United States doubts that Putin wants to negotiate an end to the invasion
The United States does not trust that Russian President Vladimir Putin is willing to negotiate an end to the invasion of Ukraine and
are considering sanctioning him
if the military escalation continues, the US State Department's Ned Price said today.
7:43 am -
Kiev claims to have shot down Russian planes, including transport ones
Ukraine claimed in the last few hours to have
shot down several Russian planes
, including a large-capacity Il-76 military transport plane with paratroopers on board.
7:39 am -
Russia. Facebook limited after refusing to suspend 'fact-checking'
Access to Facebook was restricted today in Russia after the directors of that platform refused to suspend the
"fact checking"
, as requested by the Kremlin, said Meta's vice-president, Nick Clegg.
7:36 am -
France mobilizes 500 soldiers to Romania to reinforce NATO in the region
France will deploy 500 soldiers to Romania, within the scope of NATO, to
"strengthen" the presence of the Atlantic Alliance
in the region in the face of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, the Chief of Staff of the French Armed Forces revealed this Friday.
7:32 am -
Protests in Canada, Mexico and Peru call for an end to the Russian invasion
Demonstrations on the streets of the capitals of Mexico and Peru and in Montreal, one of Canada's main cities, called, on Friday, for an end to the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Despite a snowstorm, dozens of people gathered at the Russian consulate general in Montreal to demand that Russian President Vladimir Putin
"Hands off Ukraine"
.

Antonio Guterres. Soldiers must return "to their barracks"
The UN Secretary-General, António Guterres, called for the return of "soldiers to their barracks", following the Russian veto of the United Nations' condemnation of the military offensive in Ukraine, and for the
"new chance for peace"
. "We will never give up" on achieving peace, he said.
7:25 am -
Australia imposes new round of sanctions against Russian President
The Australian Government today announced a new round of sanctions aimed directly at Russian President, Vladimir Putin, following the decision to invade Ukraine. "

Russia today vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning its aggression against Ukraine, isolated in a vote that reached 11 votes in favor and three abstentions, including from China. At issue is a

, condemning Russia, "in the strongest terms", for its "aggression against Ukraine" and asking it to "immediately" withdraw its troops from that neighboring country.

title: Ucrânia . Joe Biden aprova apoio militar de emergência a Kiev
original_title: Ucrânia. Joe Biden aprova apoio militar de emergência a Kiev
translated_title: Ukraine. Joe Biden approves emergency military support for Kiev
original_text:
J
oe Biden autorizou o Departamento de Estado norte-americano a direcionar até 250 milhões de dólares (222 milhões de euros) em ajuda geral à Ucrânia e até 350 milhões de dólares (310,5 milhões de euros) em "itens e serviços de defesa", incluindo educação e treino militar.
No entanto, o memorando não esclarece quando é que o apoio militar poderá chegar à Ucrânia, atualmente sob um ataque militar da Rússia, cujas tropas já estão a combater na capital, Kiev.
O anúncio surgiu depois de uma conversa telefónica de 40 minutos com o Presidente da Ucrânia, Volodymyr Zelensky, para discutir ajuda militar às forças de Kiev e sanções.
"Reforço das sanções, assistência concreta à defesa e uma coligação antiguerra acabaram de ser discutidos com Joe Biden", escreveu Zelensky na rede social Twitter, acrescentando estar grato pelo apoio dos Estados Unidos.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram pelo menos mais de 120 mortos, incluindo civis, e centenas de feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de 100.000 deslocados no primeiro dia de combates.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa "desmilitarizar e 'desnazificar'" o seu vizinho e que era a única maneira de o país se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário, dependendo de seus "resultados" e "relevância".
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuniões de emergência de vários governos, incluindo o português, e da Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte (NATO), União Europeia (UE) e Conselho de Segurança da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas sanções em massa contra a Rússia.

Obama pede apoio incondicional a Biden diante da invasão russa

translated_text:
J
oe Biden authorized the US State Department to direct up to $250 million (222 million euros) in general aid to Ukraine and up to $350 million (310.5 million euros) in "defense items and services", including military education and training.
However, the memo does not clarify when military support could reach Ukraine, currently under military attack from Russia, whose troops are already fighting in the capital, Kiev.
The announcement came after a 40-minute telephone conversation with the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, to discuss military aid to Kiev's forces and sanctions.
"Strengthening sanctions, concrete defense assistance and an anti-war coalition have just been discussed with Joe Biden," Zelensky wrote on the social network Twitter, adding that he was grateful for the support from the United States.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and 'denazify'" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

title: Rússia acusa Ucrânia de não ter obtido trégua ao recusar - se a negociar
original_title: Rússia acusa Ucrânia de não ter obtido trégua ao recusar-se a negociar
translated_title: Russia accuses Ukraine of failing to reach a truce by refusing to negotiate
original_text:
Início
Internacional
Rússia acusa Ucrânia de não ter obtido trégua ao recusar-se a negociar
A Rússia declarou na sexta-feira ter proposto conversações em Minsk, a capital da Bielorrússia, um aliado da Rússia e a partir da qual Moscovo lançou a sua ofensiva em Kiev. Presidente ucraniano diz que Ucrânia "quebrou o plano" russo ao terceiro dia de invasão.
© Sergei SUPINSKY / AFP
Lusa/DN
26 Fevereiro 2022 — 14:17
Facebook
Twitter
Comentar
Partilhar
Tópicos
Internacional
Guerra na Ucrânia
Relacionados
guerra na ucrânia
Zelensky diz que Ucrânia "quebrou o plano" russo ao terceiro dia de invasão
guerra na ucrânia
Moscovo ordena expansão da ofensiva acusando Kiev de recusar negociar
internacional
Alemanha decide entregar mísseis e armas anti-tanque à Ucrânia. Abramovich entrega gestão do Chelsea
O Kremlin acusou hoje a Ucrânia de não ter conseguido uma trégua devido à recusa em negociar com a Rússia.
"Ontem [sexta-feira], na expectativa de negociações, o Presidente russo ordenou uma paragem no avanço das principais forças de Moscovo", disse o porta-voz presidencial russo Dmitry Peskov.
"Uma vez que o lado ucraniano recusou as negociações, o avanço das forças russas foi retomado hoje", acrescentou.
Fechar
Subscreva as newsletters
Diário de Notícias
e receba as informações em primeira mão.
Subscrever
A Rússia declarou na sexta-feira ter proposto conversações em Minsk, a capital da Bielorrússia, um aliado da Rússia e a partir da qual Moscovo lançou a sua ofensiva em Kiev.
Algumas horas mais tarde, Vladimir Putin apelou ao exército ucraniano para encenar um golpe e descreveu o seu homólogo ucraniano Volodymyr Zelensky e a sua comitiva como "um grupo de toxicodependentes e neonazis".
Washington disse que a abertura russa não podia ser considerada credível.
Questionado sobre o número crescente de sanções, Dmitry Peskov disse que estas eram "previsíveis" e assegurou que "estão a ser tomadas medidas para minimizar o seu efeito em todos os sectores da economia".
"Então teremos de desenvolver medidas de retaliação", concluiu.
Zelensky diz que Ucrânia "quebrou o plano" russo ao terceiro dia de invasão
O Presidente ucraniano, Volodymyr Zelensky, por seu lado, garantiu hoje que "quebrou o plano" da Rússia ao terceiro dia da invasão do seu país, pedindo aos russos que digam a Vladimir Putin para parar a guerra.
"Mantivemos a nossa posição e repelimos com sucesso os ataques inimigos. Os combates continuam em muitas cidades e regiões do país, mas... é o nosso exército que controla Kiev e as principais cidades ao redor da capital", disse Zelensky, num vídeo publicado no Facebook.
Volodymyr Zelensky assegurou que as Forças Armadas da Ucrânia "desviaram" o plano de ataque russo à capital, Kiev, contra o qual a Rússia usou "de tudo" para assaltá-la, utilizando combatentes, grupos de sabotagem e tropas aerotransportadas.
"Posso começar com a boa notícia: resistimos e estamos a repelir com sucesso os ataques inimigos. A luta continua em muitas cidades e regiões do nosso país. Kiev e as principais cidades ao à volta da capital são controladas pelo nosso exército", disse o Presidente ucraniano numa nova mensagem ao país, divulgada pelo Gabinete do Presidente, citado pela Efe.
"Os ocupantes queriam bloquear o centro do país e colocar fantoches (pró-russos) aqui, como em Donetsk. Desviámos a sua intenção e eles não obtiveram nenhuma vantagem sobre nós", acrescentou.
Segundo Volodymyr Zelensky, "a verdadeira batalha por Kiev continuou". "O inimigo usou de tudo contra nós: combatentes, grupos de sabotagem e tropas de desembarque. Os invasores atingiram áreas residenciais, procurando eliminar as instalações energéticas. As suas tácticas são muito vis", acrescentou.
Pelo menos 35 pessoas ficaram feridas na passada madrugada em Kiev, incluindo duas crianças, de acordo com o balanço feito pelo presidente da câmara, Vitali Klistchko, que também informou que um míssil russo atingiu um prédio de apartamentos no oeste da cidade, e negou a presença de tropas russas regulares na cidade, após uma noite de intensos combates e tentativas do exército russo em controlar a capital da Ucrânia.

translated_text:
Home
International
Russia accuses Ukraine of failing to reach a truce by refusing to negotiate
Russia said on Friday it had proposed talks in Minsk, the capital of Belarus, an ally of Russia and from which Moscow launched its offensive on Kiev. Ukrainian president says Ukraine "broke the Russian plan" on the third day of the invasion.
© Sergei SUPINSKY / AFP
Lusa/DN
26 February 2022 — 14:17
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
International
War in Ukraine
Related
war in ukraine
Zelensky says Ukraine "broke the Russian plan" on the third day of invasion
war in ukraine
Moscow orders expansion of offensive, accusing Kiev of refusing to negotiate
international
Germany decides to deliver missiles and anti-tank weapons to Ukraine. Abramovich hands over Chelsea management
The Kremlin today accused Ukraine of failing to reach a truce due to its refusal to negotiate with Russia.
"Yesterday [Friday], in anticipation of negotiations, the Russian President ordered a halt to the advance of Moscow's main forces," said Russian presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov.
"Since the Ukrainian side refused negotiations, the advance of Russian forces resumed today," he added.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Russia said on Friday it had proposed talks in Minsk, the capital of Belarus, an ally of Russia and from which Moscow launched its offensive on Kiev.
A few hours later, Vladimir Putin called on the Ukrainian army to stage a coup and described his Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky and his entourage as "a group of drug addicts and neo-Nazis".
Washington said the Russian overture could not be considered credible.
Asked about the growing number of sanctions, Dmitry Peskov said that they were "predictable" and assured that "measures are being taken to minimize their effect on all sectors of the economy".
"Then we will have to develop retaliatory measures," he concluded.
Zelensky says Ukraine "broke the Russian plan" on the third day of invasion
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, for his part, assured today that he "broke Russia's plan" on the third day of the invasion of his country, asking the Russians to tell Vladimir Putin to stop the war.
"We maintained our position and successfully repelled enemy attacks. Fighting continues in many cities and regions of the country, but... it is our army that controls Kiev and the main cities around the capital," Zelensky said, in a video posted on Facebook.
Volodymyr Zelensky assured that the Armed Forces of Ukraine "diverted" the Russian attack plan on the capital, Kiev, against which Russia used "everything" to assault it, using fighters, sabotage groups and airborne troops.
"I can start with the good news: we resisted and are successfully repelling enemy attacks. The fighting continues in many cities and regions of our country. Kiev and the main cities around the capital are controlled by our army", said the Ukrainian President in a new message to the country, released by the President's Office, cited by Efe.
"The occupiers wanted to block the center of the country and place (pro-Russian) puppets here, like in Donetsk. We diverted their intention and they did not gain any advantage over us," he added.
According to Volodymyr Zelensky, "the real battle for Kiev continued." "The enemy used everything against us: fighters, sabotage groups and landing troops. The invaders targeted residential areas, seeking to eliminate energy installations. Their tactics are very vile," he added.
At least 35 people were injured last night in Kiev, including two children, according to the report made by the mayor, Vitali Klistchko, who also reported that a Russian missile hit an apartment building in the west of the city, and denied the presence of regular Russian troops in the city, after a night of intense fighting and attempts by the Russian army to control the Ukrainian capital.

title: Rússia fora da edio deste ano do festival da Eurovisão
original_title: Rússia fora da edição deste ano do festival da Eurovisão - SIC Notícias
translated_title: Russia out of this year's Eurovision festival - SIC Notícias
original_text:
Conflito Rússia-Ucrânia
,
Mundo
Rússia fora da edição deste ano do festival da Eurovisão
A decisão “reflete preocupação de, à luz da crise sem precedentes na Ucrânia, a inclusão de um concorrente russo no concurso deste ano poder trazer descrédito à competição”.
Facebook
Twitter
Linkedin
email
17:21 25 Fevereiro, 2022
|
SIC Notícias
A Rússia “não irá participar” no 66.º Festival Eurovisão da Canção, marcado para maio em Turim, Itália, anunciou esta sexta-feira a União Europeia de Radiodifusão (EBU), que promove o concurso.
“O Conselho Executivo da EBU tomou a decisão seguindo uma recomendação, de hoje, da organização do festival, baseada nas regras do evento e nos valores da EBU. A recomendação da organização conta também com o apoio do departamento de televisão da EBU”, lê-se num comunicado divulgado hoje à tarde no siteoficial da EBU.
Statement from
@EBU_HQ
regarding Russia's participation in the Eurovision Song Contest 2022.
https://t.co/HmKJdqVE4J
pic.twitter.com/tVH6yFxzbq
— Eurovision Song Contest (@Eurovision)
February 25, 2022
Na quarta-feira, a emissora pública da Ucrânia, numa
carta aberta, apelou à EBU para a exclusão da estação pública da Rússia da União Europeia de Radiodifusão,
apelidando-a de
“porta-voz do Kremlin e uma peça chave da propaganda politica financiada pelo Orçamento do Estado russo”.
Na mesma carta, a UA:PBC pedia que a Rússia fosse excluída do 66.º Festival Eurovisão da Canção.
Entretanto, esta sexta-feira, a emissora AVROTROS, dos Países Baixos, coorganizadora do Festival Eurovisão da Canção no ano passado, fez um apelo semelhante ao da UA:PBC.
A
Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia,
com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram pelo menos mais de 120 mortos, incluindo civis, e centenas de feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de 100.000 deslocados no primeiro dia de combates.
No comunicado esta sexta-feira divulgado, a EBU refere que
a decisão de excluir a Rússia da edição deste ano do Festival Eurovisão da Canção “reflete preocupação de, à luz da crise sem precedentes na Ucrânia, a inclusão de um concorrente russo no concurso deste ano poder trazer descrédito à competição”.
No comunicado a EBU partilha que, antes de tomar a decisão,
realizou uma “ampla consulta” dos seus membros, entre os quais figura a RTP.
“A EBU é uma organização apolítica de emissoras comprometidas com a defesa dos valores do serviço público. Continuamos dedicados a proteger os valores de uma competição cultural, que promove o intercâmbio e a compreensão internacional, aproxima públicos, celebra a diversidade através da música e une a Europa num palco”, lê-se ainda no comunicado.
A Rússia a
inda não tinha escolhido quem iria representar o país no 66.º Festival Eurovisão da Canção,
que vai decorrer entre 10 e 14 de maio, em Turim.
Entre os
agora 40 países a concurso está também a Ucrânia, que será representada pelos Kalush Orchestra, com a música “Stefania”,
em substituição de Alina Pash, a vencedora do concurso para escolher o representante do país na Eurovisão.
A 19 de fevereiro, a Ucrânia anunciou que
Alina Pash já não seria a representante do país na Eurovisão, depois de ter havido protestos devido ao facto de a cantora ter atuado na Crimeia em 2015,
um ano depois de a Rússia ter ocupado aquela região.
Esta não é a primeira vez que o
conflito entre a Rússia e a Ucrânia tem implicações na Eurovisão.
Em 2017, a Rússia recusou participar no concurso realizado em Kiev, na Ucrânia, depois de os serviços de segurança daquele país terem impedido a entrada da cantora Yulia Samoylova por esta ter visitado a Crimeia após a anexação russa.
Em 2019, a UA:PBC renunciou a participar no concurso, que nesse ano decorreu em Israel, por não ter conseguido um acordo com a vencedora do concurso para encontrar o representante do país na Eurovisão.
A cantora Maruv, que tinha vencido o concurso com a música “Siren Song” negou-se a assinar o contrato leonino proposto pela UA:PBC.
As condições do contrato incluíam recusar-se a atuar na Rússia e ser especialmente cuidadosa ao abordar o tema da integridade territorial da Ucrânia, ou fazer declarações públicas que pudessem prejudicar a imagem do país a nível internacional.

translated_text:
Russia-Ukraine conflict
,
World
Russia out of this year's Eurovision contest
The decision “reflects concern that, in light of the unprecedented crisis in Ukraine, the inclusion of a Russian competitor in this year’s contest could bring the competition into disrepute.”
Facebook
Twitter
Linkedin
email
17:21 February 25, 2022
|
SIC News
Russia “will not participate” in the 66th Eurovision Song Contest, scheduled for May in Turin, Italy, the European Broadcasting Union (EBU), which promotes the contest, announced this Friday.
"The EBU Executive Board took the decision following a recommendation from today's festival organization, based on the event rules and EBU values. The organization's recommendation also has the support of the EBU television department", reads a statement released this afternoon on the EBU's official website.
Statement from
@EBU_HQ
regarding Russia's participation in the Eurovision Song Contest 2022.
https://t.co/HmKJdqVE4J
pic.twitter.com/tVH6yFxzbq
— Eurovision Song Contest (@Eurovision)
February 25, 2022
On Wednesday, Ukraine's public broadcaster, in a
open letter, called on the EBU to exclude Russia's public broadcaster from the European Broadcasting Union,
naming her
“spokesperson for the Kremlin and a key piece of political propaganda financed by the Russian State Budget”.
In the same letter, UA:PBC asked that Russia be excluded from the 66th Eurovision Song Contest.
However, this Friday, broadcaster AVROTROS, from the Netherlands, co-organizer of the Eurovision Song Contest last year, made a similar appeal to that of UA:PBC.
A
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning,
with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
In the statement released this Friday, the EBU states that
The decision to exclude Russia from this year's Eurovision Song Contest "reflects concern that, in light of the unprecedented crisis in Ukraine, the inclusion of a Russian contestant in this year's contest could bring the competition into disrepute."
In the statement, the EBU shares that, before making the decision,
carried out a “broad consultation” of its members, including RTP.
"The EBU is an apolitical organization of broadcasters committed to defending the values ​​of public service. We remain dedicated to protecting the values ​​of a cultural competition, which promotes international exchange and understanding, brings audiences together, celebrates diversity through music and unites Europe on one stage", the statement further reads.
Russia to
had not yet chosen who would represent the country in the 66th Eurovision Song Contest,
which will take place between May 10th and 14th, in Turin.
Among the
now 40 countries in the competition there is also Ukraine, which will be represented by the Kalush Orchestra, with the song “Stefania”,
replacing Alina Pash, the winner of the contest to choose the country's representative at Eurovision.
On February 19, Ukraine announced that
Alina Pash would no longer be the country's representative at Eurovision, after there were protests over the fact that the singer performed in Crimea in 2015,
a year after Russia occupied that region.
This is not the first time that the
conflict between Russia and Ukraine has implications for Eurovision.
In 2017, Russia refused to participate in the competition held in Kiev, Ukraine, after that country's security services prevented singer Yulia Samoylova from entering because she had visited Crimea after the Russian annexation.
In 2019, UA:PBC withdrew from participating in the contest, which took place in Israel that year, as it was unable to reach an agreement with the winner of the contest to find the country's representative at Eurovision.
Singer Maruv, who had won the competition with the song “Siren Song”, refused to sign the leonine contract proposed by UA:PBC.
The conditions of the contract included refusing to operate in Russia and being especially careful when addressing the issue of Ukraine's territorial integrity, or making public statements that could damage the country's image internationally.

title: Kiev alerta que Rússia quer levar negociaes para  um beco sem saída
original_title: Kiev alerta que Rússia quer levar negociações para "um beco sem saída" — DNOTICIAS.PT
translated_title: Kiev warns that Russia wants to lead negotiations to "a dead end" — DNOTICIAS.PT
original_text:
A Guerra
Mundo
Kiev alerta que Rússia quer levar negociações para "um beco sem saída"
Agência Lusa
26 fev 2022
17:58
0
Comentários
EPA/ZURAB KURTSIKIDZE
A Ucrânia acusou hoje a Rússia de querer levar as eventuais negociações para parar a guerra para um "beco sem saída, antes de começarem" afirmando falsamente que Kiev se nega a dialogar e que põe condições.
"Os seus comentários de que supostamente nos recusamos a negociar são apenas parte das suas táticas. Estão a tentar levar as negociações para um beco sem saída, antes mesmo de começarem", disse o assessor do chefe do Gabinete da Presidência ucraniana, Mykhailo Podoliak.
O Kremlin declarou horas antes que o Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, ordenou na sexta-feira que parasse a ofensiva do exército russo na Ucrânia, aguardando uma resposta de Kiev sobre um processo de negociação para interromper a guerra, mas que deu ordens para o seu reinício após acusar o seu homólogo ucraniano, Volodymyr Zelensky, de recusar o diálogo.
Segundo o porta-voz do presidente russo, Dmitri Peskov, "ontem [sexta-feira], devido a negociações pendentes com a liderança ucraniana, o comandante-chefe russo e o Presidente ordenaram a interrupção do avanço da grande maioria das tropas".
"Como o lado ucraniano essencialmente rejeitou as negociações, o avanço das tropas russas foi retomado hoje de acordo com o plano da operação", adiantou Peskov.
"A mentira dos russos de que supostamente tinham ordem de parar é desmentida pela própria realidade que o mundo inteiro viu na noite de sábado. E hoje de manhã. A luta foi feroz e a sua intensidade máxima", comentou Podoliak.
E adiantou: "É justamente por isso que o Presidente [Volodymyr] Zelensky não aceita categoricamente quaisquer condições e ultimatos (...), apenas negociações completas".
O ministro dos Negócios Estrangeiros da Rússia, Sergei Lavrov, deixou claro na sexta-feira qual é a condição para que a Rússia negoceie.
Segundo o chefe da diplomacia russa, o diálogo só será possível "após a restauração da ordem democrática na Ucrânia", ou seja, após uma mudança de governo em Kiev.
Na sexta-feira, o Presidente Putin exortou o exército ucraniano a "tomar o poder".
A Rússia diz que a ofensiva visa "desmilitarizar e desnazificar" a Ucrânia, depois de ter exigido que o país nunca entre para a NATO (Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte).
Zelensky declarou na noite de quinta-feira, após o primeiro dia da invasão russa, que estava disposto a discutir a neutralidade do seu país em relação à Aliança Atlântica em troca de garantias para a Ucrânia.
"Qualquer guerra inevitavelmente termina com negociações", declarou na ocasião.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram pelo menos 198 mortos, incluindo civis, e mais de 1.100 feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de 120.000 deslocados desde o primeiro dia de combates.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de o país se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuniões de emergência de vários governos, incluindo o português, e da Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte (NATO), UE e Conselho de Segurança da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas sanções em massa contra a Rússia.

translated_text:
The War
World
Kiev warns that Russia wants to lead negotiations to "a dead end"
Lusa Agency
Feb 26, 2022
17:58
0
Comments
EPA/ZURAB KURTSIKIDZE
Ukraine today accused Russia of wanting to bring any negotiations to stop the war to a "dead end before they start" falsely stating that Kiev refuses to dialogue and that it sets conditions.
"Their comments that we supposedly refuse to negotiate are just part of their tactics. They are trying to lead the negotiations to a dead end before they even begin," said advisor to the head of the Ukrainian President's Office, Mykhailo Podoliak.
The Kremlin declared hours earlier that Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered on Friday to stop the Russian army's offensive in Ukraine, awaiting a response from Kiev on a negotiation process to stop the war, but that he gave orders for its restart after accusing his Ukrainian counterpart, Volodymyr Zelensky, of refusing dialogue.
According to the Russian President's spokesman, Dmitri Peskov, "yesterday [Friday], due to pending negotiations with the Ukrainian leadership, the Russian Commander-in-Chief and the President ordered a halt to the advance of the vast majority of troops."
"As the Ukrainian side essentially rejected the negotiations, the advance of Russian troops resumed today in accordance with the operation plan," Peskov said.
"The Russians' lie that they supposedly had orders to stop is contradicted by the very reality that the whole world saw on Saturday night. And this morning. The fighting was fierce and at its maximum intensity," commented Podoliak.
And he added: "This is precisely why President [Volodymyr] Zelensky categorically does not accept any conditions and ultimatums (...), only complete negotiations."
Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov made it clear on Friday what the condition is for Russia to negotiate.
According to the head of Russian diplomacy, dialogue will only be possible "after the restoration of democratic order in Ukraine", that is, after a change of government in Kiev.
On Friday, President Putin called on the Ukrainian army to "seize power."
Russia says the offensive aims to "demilitarize and denazify" Ukraine, after demanding that the country never join NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organization).
Zelensky declared on Thursday night, after the first day of the Russian invasion, that he was willing to discuss his country's neutrality towards the Atlantic Alliance in exchange for guarantees for Ukraine.
"Any war inevitably ends with negotiations," he declared at the time.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 198 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 120,000 people displaced since the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

title: Zelensky diz que Ucrânia ″ quebrou o plano ″ russo ao terceiro dia de invasão
original_title: Zelensky diz que Ucrânia ″quebrou o plano″ russo ao terceiro dia de invasão
translated_title: Zelensky says Ukraine “broke the Russian plan” on the third day of invasion
original_text:
Início
Internacional
Zelensky diz que Ucrânia "quebrou o plano" russo ao terceiro dia de invasão
"Os ocupantes queriam bloquear o centro do país e colocar fantoches (pró-russos) aqui, como em Donetsk. Desviámos a sua intenção e eles não obtiveram nenhuma vantagem sobre nós", disse o presidente ucraniano.

internacional
Rússia acusa Ucrânia de não ter obtido trégua ao recusar-se a negociar
guerra na ucrânia
Moscovo ordena expansão da ofensiva acusando Kiev de recusar negociar
O Presidente ucraniano, Volodymyr Zelensky, garantiu hoje que "quebrou o plano" da Rússia ao terceiro dia da invasão do seu país, pedindo aos russos que digam a Vladimir Putin para parar a guerra.
"Mantivemos a nossa posição e repelimos com sucesso os ataques inimigos. Os combates continuam em muitas cidades e regiões do país, mas... é o nosso exército que controla Kiev e as principais cidades ao redor da capital", disse Zelensky, num vídeo publicado no Facebook.
Volodymyr Zelensky assegurou que as Forças Armadas da Ucrânia "desviaram" o plano de ataque russo à capital, Kiev, contra o qual a Rússia usou "de tudo" para assaltá-la, utilizando combatentes, grupos de sabotagem e tropas aerotransportadas.
Fechar
Subscreva as newsletters

e receba as informações em primeira mão.
Subscrever
"Posso começar com a boa notícia: resistimos e estamos a repelir com sucesso os ataques inimigos. A luta continua em muitas cidades e regiões do nosso país. Kiev e as principais cidades ao à volta da capital são controladas pelo nosso exército", disse o Presidente ucraniano numa nova mensagem ao país, divulgada pelo Gabinete do Presidente, citado pela Efe.
"Os ocupantes queriam bloquear o centro do país e colocar fantoches (pró-russos) aqui, como em Donetsk. Desviámos a sua intenção e eles não obtiveram nenhuma vantagem sobre nós", acrescentou.
Segundo Volodymyr Zelensky, "a verdadeira batalha por Kiev continuou". "O inimigo usou de tudo contra nós: combatentes, grupos de sabotagem e tropas de desembarque. Os invasores atingiram áreas residenciais, procurando eliminar as instalações energéticas. As suas tácticas são muito vis", acrescentou.
Pelo menos 35 pessoas ficaram feridas na passada madrugada em Kiev, incluindo duas crianças, de acordo com o balanço feito pelo presidente da câmara, Vitali Klistchko, que também informou que um míssil russo atingiu um prédio de apartamentos no oeste da cidade, e negou a presença de tropas russas regulares na cidade, após uma noite de intensos combates e tentativas do exército russo em controlar a capital da Ucrânia.
Zelensky frisou, no seu discurso, que os combates continuam em muitas partes do país - como Sumy (nordeste), Kharkov (leste) ou Chernigov (norte) - e exortou todos os ucranianos a regressar à Ucrânia e defender seu país.
Em Donbas, de acordo com a Administração Estatal da região de Lugansk, o exército perdeu o controlo de Stanitsia Luganska, Krymske e Markivka, segundo a agência UNIAN.
O Ministério da Defesa da Rússia também garantiu hoje que as Forças Armadas russas garantiram o controlo total sobre a cidade de Melitopol, perto do Mar de Azov.
"Os militares russos estão a tomar todas as medidas para garantir a segurança dos civis e para excluir as provocações dos serviços especiais e nacionalistas ucranianos", refere um comunicado.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram pelo menos 198 mortos, incluindo civis, e mais de 1.100 feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de 120.000 deslocados desde o primeiro dia de combates.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de o país se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuniões de emergência de vários governos, incluindo o português, e da Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte (NATO), UE e Conselho de Segurança da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas sanções em massa contra a Rússia.

translated_text:
Home
International
Zelensky says Ukraine "broke the Russian plan" on the third day of invasion
"The occupiers wanted to block the center of the country and place (pro-Russian) puppets here, like in Donetsk. We deviated from their intention and they did not gain any advantage over us," said the Ukrainian president.
© DR
Lusa/DN
26 February 2022 — 12:49
Facebook
Twitter

Topics
War in Ukraine

Related
international

international
Russia accuses Ukraine of failing to reach a truce by refusing to negotiate
war in ukraine
Moscow orders expansion of offensive, accusing Kiev of refusing to negotiate
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky assured today that he "broke Russia's plan" on the third day of the invasion of his country, asking Russians to tell Vladimir Putin to stop the war.
"We maintained our position and successfully repelled enemy attacks. Fighting continues in many cities and regions of the country, but... it is our army that controls Kiev and the main cities around the capital," Zelensky said, in a video posted on Facebook.
Volodymyr Zelensky assured that the Armed Forces of Ukraine "diverted" the Russian attack plan on the capital, Kiev, against which Russia used "everything" to assault it, using fighters, sabotage groups and airborne troops.
Close

Subscribe
"I can start with the good news: we resisted and are successfully repelling enemy attacks. The fighting continues in many cities and regions of our country. Kiev and the main cities around the capital are controlled by our army", said the Ukrainian President in a new message to the country, released by the President's Office, cited by Efe.
"The occupiers wanted to block the center of the country and place (pro-Russian) puppets here, like in Donetsk. We diverted their intention and they did not gain any advantage over us," he added.
According to Volodymyr Zelensky, "the real battle for Kiev continued." "The enemy used everything against us: fighters, sabotage groups and landing troops. The invaders targeted residential areas, seeking to eliminate energy installations. Their tactics are very vile," he added.
At least 35 people were injured last night in Kiev, including two children, according to the report made by the mayor, Vitali Klistchko, who also reported that a Russian missile hit an apartment building in the west of the city, and denied the presence of regular Russian troops in the city, after a night of intense fighting and attempts by the Russian army to control the Ukrainian capital.
Zelensky stressed, in his speech, that fighting continues in many parts of the country - such as Sumy (northeast), Kharkov (east) or Chernigov (north) - and urged all Ukrainians to return to Ukraine and defend their country.
In Donbas, according to the State Administration of the Lugansk region, the army lost control of Stanitsia Luganska, Krymske and Markivka, according to the UNIAN agency.
The Russian Defense Ministry also assured today that the Russian Armed Forces have secured full control over the city of Melitopol, near the Sea of ​​Azov.
"The Russian military is taking all measures to ensure the safety of civilians and to exclude provocations by the special services and Ukrainian nationalists," a statement said.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 198 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 120,000 people displaced since the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.

title: Putin terá mandado tropas russas parar invasão ontem , diz o Kremlin
original_title: Putin terá mandado tropas russas parar invasão ontem, diz o Kremlin
translated_title: Putin ordered Russian troops to stop invasion yesterday, says Kremlin
original_text:
V
ladimir Putin terá ordenado que as tropas russas parassem a invasão à Ucrânia, afirma o Kremlin. O pedido terá sido feito na sexta-feira, mas ainda assim, os militares continuaram a avançar rumo a Kiev.
A informação está a ser avançada pela Sky News que refere que se crê que as tropas russas estarão a cerca de 30 quilómetros do centro de Kiev. Um ministro ucraniano refere, contudo, que poderão estar mais próximos que isso.
O porta-voz presidencial russo, Dmitry Peskov, disse que
"ontem [sexta-feira], na expectativa de negociações, o presidente russo ordenou uma paragem no avanço das principais forças de Moscovo"
.
"Uma vez que o lado ucraniano recusou as negociações, o avanço das forças russas foi retomado hoje"
, acrescentou.
A Rússia declarou na sexta-feira ter proposto conversações em Minsk, a capital da Bielorrússia, um aliado da Rússia e a partir da qual Moscovo lançou a sua ofensiva em Kiev.
Algumas horas mais tarde, Vladimir Putin apelou ao exército ucraniano para encenar um golpe e descreveu o seu homólogo ucraniano Volodymyr Zelensky e a sua comitiva como "um grupo de toxicodependentes e neonazis".
Washington disse que a abertura russa não podia ser considerada credível.
Questionado sobre o número crescente de sanções, Dmitry Peskov disse que estas eram "previsíveis" e assegurou que "estão a ser tomadas medidas para minimizar o seu efeito em todos os sectores da economia". "Então teremos de desenvolver medidas de retaliação", concluiu.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram pelo menos 198 mortos, incluindo civis, e mais de 1.100 feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de 120.000 deslocados desde o primeiro dia de combates.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa desmilitarizar o país vizinho e que era a única maneira de o país se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário.
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuniões de emergência de vários governos, incluindo o português, e da Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte (NATO), UE e Conselho de Segurança da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas sanções em massa contra a Rússia.
[Notícia atualizada às 13h54]

translated_text:
V
ladimir Putin ordered Russian troops to stop the invasion of Ukraine, says the Kremlin. The request was made on Friday, but the military continued to advance towards Kiev.
The information is being provided by Sky News, which states that it is believed that Russian troops will be around 30 kilometers from the center of Kiev. A Ukrainian minister says, however, that they could be closer than that.
Russian presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that
"yesterday [Friday], in anticipation of negotiations, the Russian president ordered a halt to the advance of Moscow's main forces"
.
"Since the Ukrainian side refused negotiations, the advance of Russian forces resumed today"
, he added.
Russia said on Friday it had proposed talks in Minsk, the capital of Belarus, an ally of Russia and from which Moscow launched its offensive on Kiev.
A few hours later, Vladimir Putin called on the Ukrainian army to stage a coup and described his Ukrainian counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky and his entourage as "a group of drug addicts and neo-Nazis".
Washington said the Russian overture could not be considered credible.
Asked about the growing number of sanctions, Dmitry Peskov said that they were "predictable" and assured that "measures are being taken to minimize their effect on all sectors of the economy". "Then we will have to develop retaliatory measures," he concluded.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least 198 deaths, including civilians, and more than 1,100 injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 120,000 people displaced since the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to demilitarize the neighboring country and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin stating that the offensive will last as long as necessary.
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), EU and UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.
[News updated at 1:54 pm]

original_text:
A Guerra

Um grande edifício residencial em Kiev foi atingido por um míssil, indicou hoje à AFP o serviço do Estado para as questões de emergência, sem dar informações quanto a eventuais vítimas.
O míssil atingiu o edifício entre o 18.º e o 21.º andar, precisou este serviço do estado ucraniano, acrescentando que a evacuação do prédio estava "em curso".
A Rússia havia anunciado um pouco antes ter disparado mísseis de cruzeiro, ao terceiro dia da sua invasão da Ucrânia.
O presidente da Câmara de Kiev, Vitali Klitschko, referiu que o prédio situa-se nos arredores da capital ucraniana, perto do aeroporto de Zhuliany, de acordo com informações recolhidas pela Associated Press (AP).
Através de uma aplicação de mensagens, Vitali Klitschko publicou uma imagem do prédio mostrando que o míssil atingiu apartamentos e várias lojas.
A Rússia lançou na quinta-feira de madrugada uma ofensiva militar na Ucrânia, com forças terrestres e bombardeamento de alvos em várias cidades, que já provocaram pelo menos mais de 120 mortos, incluindo civis, e centenas de feridos, em território ucraniano, segundo Kiev. A ONU deu conta de 100.000 deslocados no primeiro dia de combates.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, disse que a "operação militar especial" na Ucrânia visa "desmilitarizar e 'desnazificar'" o seu vizinho e que era a única maneira de o país se defender, precisando o Kremlin que a ofensiva durará o tempo necessário, dependendo de seus "resultados" e "relevância".
O ataque foi condenado pela generalidade da comunidade internacional e motivou reuniões de emergência de vários governos, incluindo o português, e da Organização do Tratado do Atlântico Norte (NATO), União Europeia (UE) e Conselho de Segurança da ONU, tendo sido aprovadas sanções em massa contra a Rússia.

Video of the moment a missile hits a residential building in Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 26, 2022
09:22
0
Comments
A large residential building in Kiev was hit by a missile, the State service for emergency issues told AFP today, without providing information about possible victims.
The missile hit the building between the 18th and 21st floors, this Ukrainian state service said, adding that the evacuation of the building was "underway".
Russia had announced shortly before that it had fired cruise missiles, on the third day of its invasion of Ukraine.
The Mayor of Kiev, Vitali Klitschko, said that the building is located on the outskirts of the Ukrainian capital, close to Zhuliany airport, according to information collected by the Associated Press (AP).
Through a messaging application, Vitali Klitschko published an image of the building showing that the missile hit apartments and several stores.
Russia launched a military offensive in Ukraine early Thursday morning, with ground forces and bombing of targets in several cities, which has already caused at least more than 120 deaths, including civilians, and hundreds of injuries, on Ukrainian territory, according to Kiev. The UN reported 100,000 people displaced on the first day of fighting.
Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the "special military operation" in Ukraine aims to "demilitarize and 'denazify'" its neighbor and that it was the only way for the country to defend itself, with the Kremlin specifying that the offensive will last as long as necessary, depending on its "results" and "relevance".
The attack was condemned by most of the international community and led to emergency meetings of several governments, including the Portuguese, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), European Union (EU) and the UN Security Council, with mass sanctions being approved against Russia.
